the game that started every FPS game possible (if it wasnt for Quake ofc)
man, what a game! i remember being my first FPS game i played. the plot, characters, design when i was a kid was completely amazing, and it still is. i love how Half-Life franchise started here, from a simple GldSrc game to a Source one. not to talk about its betas/prototypes, expansion packs (Blue Shift, Opposing Force, Decay...) and many mods (official like Counter-Strike and Team Fortress / non-official like They Hunger and Echoes). those are an extra of what the GldSrc Engine game are capable of.
concluting that Half-Life is still worth playing at the present times, in Story Mode, Multiplayer Games and in-depth stories, mysteries and experiences about the games/franchise just to place together the pieces of the puzzle.

Even though some levels of this game felt slacking, the ending was satisfying and I ended up wanting more. This game aged really well and if you can just ignore the graphics, you'll have a fun experience. 11/10 would beat the shit out of head crabs again.

I can see why this game was not only influential in first person shooters, but also in video games in general. This is probably one of the first action games to have a deep story and prove that both RPGs and adventure games are no longer the only ones that could tell stories.

Very fun game that I played in this god forsaken pandemic, good for horror-ish shooting. If you don't like that, then you won't like this. It's also jank as fuck but it doesn't ruin the experience for me, but it might for players who don't like that. Also this game is hard as shit. I'm not exactly an expert gamer:tm: so I had to play on easy for me to get anywhere at all, so keep that in mind and even then I save-scummed alot.

I like most of the weapons that aren't the shotgun since they're fun and they get their use in most situations (except the shotgun). The sound-mixing is really good at creating that atmosphere. There are also little things that I really like such as the dialogue from the npcs or the fact that the ai for the human enemies is actually pretty smart, creating a good challenge. 

Has a few flaws that are definitely noticeable. First is the lack of subtitles, which can be modded in, but if you do, the save files for the original game will not be compatible so you will have to start over with the mod specifically. I think that valve should've added a patch with subtitles in the game itself considering it's been over 20 years. Xen and the final boss are the jankiest of the jank in the whole game with bad platforming being a core element of these last few stages. Chapter 7 + 8 are probably my least favorite outside Xen because I think the enemy from c7 should've been slightly nerfed (not a fan of it in general) and c8 is slow as fuck and kinda boring. The fact that the guard and scientist models are mostly the exact same annoys me a bit, especially since there's no women at all in the game. These aspects didn't ruin the game for me, but I probably won't be replaying it soon, though I would still recommend it to players who like challenging shooters with 1998 jank.

[h1]HOW THE FUCK IS THIS GAME CONSIDERED EVEN REMOTELY GOOD[/h1]

[h1] Reseña Sobre Half life, ¿Es una obra maestra? [/h1]

Bueno, se que este analisis tengo debiente hace 4 años, pero en fin, Half life es uno de mis juegos favoritos, e incluso en mi opinion personal, es una obra maestra tal y como es, al igual si tiene con texturas HD pack o sin ellas, Half life en conclusión, fue un juego de mi infancia, la cual le tengo cariño, se que sus gráficos son feos para esta época, pero el hecho que los ignorantes diría que este juego es feo, pero para mi es una obra maestra de la revolución de juegos en 3D, con este juego ha crecido juegos como counter strike o team fortress, hasta inclusos mods para el half life como Azure Sheep o Residual life, en lo cual este juego es una obra maestra en la hora de jugar, su historia es increíble, y su jugabilidad retro es lo que le hace ver half life, como unos de los grandes juegos que se haya visto, y seguirá siendo en época actual, le doy una calificación de 10/10, es perfecto, es una obra maestra, les recomiendo muchisimo, Gracias Valve por este juego, siendo que su primer juego es una obra recordará por toda la comunidad, Gracias.

Lo acabo de volver a terminar después de casi veinte años de haberlo jugado, allá en mis años mozos con el ps2. Pocos juegos envejecen tan bien, me imagino que será como esas joyas de la literatura que durante siglos seguirá gustando a cierto sector del gaming, imperdible.

THE GAME THAT STARTED IT ALL
Back in the 1990s, First Person Shooters were nearly all identical in design philosophy, with your game either being Doom, or a Doom clone.  Every new FPS had the same formula, with its own stylistic changes, Doom was a Sci Fi game with light horror elements, Duke Nukem 3D was a ode to 80s action flicks, and Quake, while being in 3D, was just Doom with a darker tone. That is in no means a diss to these games, they are all great games from this time period, and my profile picture is Duke Nukem right now for crying out loud, but it was the truth. FPS games hadn't had a real major change in terms of gameplay, and by 1998 it was getting old. You can only go so far rehashing the same type of game before it gets old, and it was very true for the Doom type shooters. 

And this is where our savior GabeN steps in.

Back in 1996 two former Microsoft developers Gabe Newell and Mike Harrington formed their own Game studio in Valve, and quickly  began work on Half-Life. Releasing in 1998 it was a huge success, surpassing anyone's expectations.  Critics praised it to the sun, and the consumers came out in droves to buy it. Very few game developers can make as big an impact with their first game as Valve did with Half-Life. For example iD software,  the developers of the father of FPS games Doom, started out with the mediocre Commander Keen, a Mario clone for PC, and the successful, but not majorly so Wolfenstein 3D before they got to Doom. Even Nintendo, the most iconic game company of them all, took over a decade to release a hit game, and that is without mentioning the near 90 years before they were making Video Games. But what made this game so huge?

It may seem hard to believe now, but Half-Life was mind blowing in 1998. This was a FPS game with a great story, great graphics (at the time), and groundbreaking gameplay. The games story seems rather simple today, but back in 1998 this was revolutionary. Remember that this was a time before stories were common in games. Most games, especially first person shooters, would have only the bare minimum of a story, for example Doom's story is basically just Demons break through a portal from hell to a human colony on Mars, and to even know that you would need to read the manual Doom shipped with. I still don't even know what Quake 1's story is supposed to be about, if there even is one. Half-Life did things completely different, by opening the game with a bit of a slow burn tram ride into your work, the Black Mesa Research Facility. Once you get off the train you are met by a Security guard, who may or may not be Barney Calhoun who brings up your running late. You soon run into a scientist who tells you that they are waiting for you in the test chamber in perhaps one of the most unsettling ways possible, which is an excellent use of foreshadowing. Before you head there you must go to your Locker room and grab your HEV suit, and maybe blow up some guys microwave casserole on the way. You arrive at the test chamber shove some alien rock into a machine and then everything goes to utter shit, with you briefly teleporting into an alien world, and return with Black Mesa overrun with aliens, and utter carnage. I won't spoil anymore, as there are a few more twists throughout the campaign that it is best you don't know about if you don't know already. 

The gameplay in Half Life is pretty standard, with a collection of your standard FPS weapons, such as the Pistol, Revolver, Shotgun, Assault Rifle (complete with a scarface style grenade launcher attachment), and a somewhat unique weapon in the crossbow. But before you get any of these, you start with a trusty Crowbar, which has in turn became an iconic part of not just half-life, but Valve as a whole. It's a slow burn to get these weapons, and you don't want to overuse them when you do get them as ammo is limited, so it is best to use the right weapons for the right enemies. There are some more unique weapons in the game as well, but it is best to let you discover those yourself in my opinion. 

The enemies in Half Life are all quite iconic now, with the Headcrab, Valves own version of the Alien Facehuggers, the 'Zombies' which are human corpses take over by said headcrabs, Vortigaunts, which are a really unique alien who can shoot orbs and teleport and an array of others, many of which are best encountered going in blind. 

As you progress through Black Mesa you will come across many scripted events that allow the game to tell its story without forcing you out of the gameplay once which is something that even to this day is unique and quite awesome. 

The graphics were great at the time, but didn't age very well looking back, which is too be expected when returning to a game from over 20 years ago. 

And if that isn't enough to sell how damn important this game is, release this is the game that the original Counter-Strike was a mod for, and also the game that Team Fortress Classic was a mod for. Both games Valve scooped up and started selling physically with Half-Life in a bundle that lead to this very platform, Steam, created so Valve could keep Counter-Strike and any other games they make up to date easily. 

Now no game is perfect and let me get this clear to end this review their are some decently large flaws with this game which boils down to 2 things. The platforming sections, which aren't terrible, but don't really fit in either, and the elephant in the room, the last 2 hours of the game. The platforming is easy to excuse as at the time it wasn't bad and was pretty decent, but it is the section of the game that has aged the worst, the last 2 hours of the game on the other hand, were lackluster even for 1998 standards, and Gabe Newell himself has stated it is the one thing he wish he could change in a Valve game. There are also a few other sections that haven't aged well, most notably the section on a rail, where you need to take an annoying raid on a kart, but aside from these 3 problems, the game has aged very well. 

Overall I 100% recommend you play this game, preferably before you play Half-Life 2 which has aged a bit better,  as for $10 normally and as low as  $0.99 on sale it's a no brainer,  where you can't go wrong. I also strongly advise you stay far away from Valve's official Source port of the game Half-Life Source with the exceptions being if your buying the Valve Complete Pack or play Gmod and really want OG Half-Life materials.

Definitely shows its age but a very good time so far! Best played with a friend in voice chat so you can make jokes about Gordon opening doors by headbutting them. Props for not having that issue older games seem to have where Tabbing out makes it next to impossible to tab back in. That's probably the most impressive part to me since Bioshock has that issue and it came out like 10 years after this game.

Hay que ser sincero con este juego. No importa cuanto tiempo trascurra, Half Life ya quedo inmortalizado para el resto de la historia. Juego insuperable, si lo jugaste el dia en el que salio, era la mas grande divinidad. Hoy en dia a muchos les parecera que esta feo, pero es porque el tiempo pasa y las mecanicas se innovan. Solo voy a decir esto, ningun juego podra alcanzar el nivel que alcanzo este FPS en cuanto a epocas. Por que si doom era Religion en esos dias, Half Life era leyenda para todos.
